text: I don't know that it's that bid a deal. SAIS and its ilk have been open for half a century or more. I agree that there's something of an EMBA quality to some of the programs but the top ones are actually pretty good--and most employ serious scholar-practitioners.
author: DrJJoyner

text: But I'm not sure what any of that has to do with the quality of IR scholarship. Elite universities tend to have whole separate departments or schools for the public policy and academic programs. (Harvard's Kennedy School vs their regular Government program, e.g.)
author: DrJJoyner

text: There's a weirdness stemming from IR being both an academic discipline and a practice. Most diplomats are non-PhDs, whereas the PhD is pretty much required to practice economics at the public policy level. But most practitioners don't publish in scholarly journals.

text:
It turns out that the Abel Prize was established two years after the release of "Good Will Hunting," where most non-mathematicians likely first heard of the Fields Medal.

Surveys seem to show the much older FM remains more prestigious, but one recent survey puts Abel #1.
author: DrJJoyner

text: Interestingly, the Abel Prize didn't even exist when "Good Will Hunting" was released.

text: Yes. I was in grad school during the early part of the Yugoslav Wars and teaching during the rest. I raised a lot of eyebrows noting that "ethnic cleansing" was how we build the damn place. (I also referred to Milosevic as the Yugoslav Abraham Lincoln.) Ah, simpler times.
author: DrJJoyner

text: Yes. There was a litany of writing at the time, including from the likes of Teddy Roosevelt, lamenting that the tests of manhood the frontier brought had gone away.
author: DrJJoyner

text: Haven't read it yet but I extrapolated from a lot of the primary source pieces we use from the period. Ironically, the prof who chose them did so to illustrate an American Greatness narrative. But it doesn't take a lot of wokeness to see the other side of it.
author: DrJJoyner

text: Certainly true. But most people just stop growing at some point. And even a really progressive POV becomes retrograde half a century in.
author: DrJJoyner

text: What comes around goes around. After all, while Westward expansion/Manifest Destiny was foreign policy it was domestic. As I tell my students, we had a large Army mostly to keep the Indians from stealing our land.
author: DrJJoyner

text: Yeah, we actually talk about the former quite a lot as part of the origins of US foreign policy and the shift from Washington's isolationist vision to Wilson's internationalist. The latter is interesting, though.
